body_html:
Yep the only missing feature is x.transpose() which defaults to reverse all dimensions. This is in numpy but not our permute. Should be easy to add.
Agreed on the changing API is confusing, but keeping them is also confusing for new users. Now we have two options.

  1. Rename permute to transpose and transpose to swapaxes to match numpy behavior. Add x.transpose() API to transpose. So everything matches numpy.
  2. Update our doc saying permute is numpy.transpose and transpose is numpy.swapaxes. Add x.permute() API to permute to match numpy.transpose behavior. Sounds confusing to new users but is friendly to existing users.
    cc: @soumith @apaszke
body_text:
Yep the only missing feature is x.transpose() which defaults to reverse all dimensions. This is in numpy but not our permute. Should be easy to add.
Agreed on the changing API is confusing, but keeping them is also confusing for new users. Now we have two options.

Rename permute to transpose and transpose to swapaxes to match numpy behavior. Add x.transpose() API to transpose. So everything matches numpy.
Update our doc saying permute is numpy.transpose and transpose is numpy.swapaxes. Add x.permute() API to permute to match numpy.transpose behavior. Sounds confusing to new users but is friendly to existing users.
cc: @soumith @apaszke
body:
Yep the only missing feature is `x.transpose()` which defaults to reverse all dimensions. This is in numpy but not our `permute`. Should be easy to add.  
Agreed on the changing API is confusing, but keeping them is also confusing for new users. Now we have two options. 
1. Rename `permute` to `transpose` and `transpose` to `swapaxes` to match numpy behavior. Add x.transpose() API to `transpose`. So everything matches numpy.
2. Update our doc saying `permute` is `numpy.transpose` and `transpose` is `numpy.swapaxes`. Add x.permute() API to `permute` to match `numpy.transpose` behavior. Sounds confusing to new users but is friendly to existing users. 
cc: @soumith @apaszke
